Tell Black Lawmakers:
We need Internet freedom


  • if in the US click here
Not ? Click here.

If you enter your phone number, we'll call you and connect you with the office of the CBC. We'll suggest a script you can read to ask them to stand up for net neutrality.

* denotes required fields

If your phone number is based outside of the U.S., it won't work with this call tool.

You will receive periodic updates from ColorOfChange.org. You may unsubscribe at any time.

Tell Black Lawmakers:
We need Internet freedom

Net neutrality is fueling a new Internet-powered civil rights movement. But the big phone and cable companies want to destroy net neutrality to increase their profits.

Congressional Black Caucus members like Keith Ellison and Maxine Waters are fighting for net neutrality. But some CBC representatives are joining the telecom lobby in attacking net neutrality, even supporting Republican efforts to attack President Obama’s legacy and block the Federal Communications Commission from doing it’s job.

Meanwhile others have so far remained silent.

Everyone who cares about civil rights and the power of self-determination should be fighting for net neutrality. Please take a moment to call members of the CBC who haven’t taken a position, and make sure they know it’s a critical civil rights issue.

We're calling you now!

We'll connect you with the office of a CBC member who hasn’t taken a position on net neutrality, and keep connecting you to offices until you hang up. When they answer, please be polite, and say:

I’m calling because our communities need you to stand up for net neutrality. Net neutrality keeps the Internet diverse and open, and gives individuals and businesses an equal chance online. It’s also fueling a new civil rights movement, helping us to engage in a political process that has been historically exclusive. Everyone who cares about civil rights should fight for net neutrality.

Please support the Federal Communications Commission in implementing strong net neutrality rules under Title II of the Telecommunications Act.
